awd_titl_txt: QMHP: Entanglement and Coherence Decay in Nanosystems and Applications to Quantum Information Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
ENTANGLEMENT AND COHERENCE DECAY IN NANOSYSTEMS AND APPLICATIONS TO
QUANTUM INFORMATION SYSTEMS

Objectives and Approaches: Entanglement is at the heart of the vast
improvement in encryption systems and will hopefully provide the backbone
of quantum information systems in general, particularly quantum
computing.Since the Josephson System arrays, being pursued experimentally
by the Yale and Santa Barbara groups, show great promise, a theoretical
analysis of this work will be carried out, using exact methods, as distinct from the master equations presently being used by others.In particular,the effect of temperature on large systems will be emphasized since,even for small systems, it has been found that moderate temperatures can cause disentanglement and that the effect is constant for all times.

Intellectual Merit : Understanding the physical world relies heavily on Quantum Mechanics. But, many questions remain concerning its foundations. In particular, the heart of quantum mechanics is entanglement but, as emphasized by Feynman, among others, its nature essentially remains unknown .Thus, a strong effort will be made to understand it more deeply.

Broader Benefits: Ironically, entanglement is a tool which is essentially used in all modern quantum systems, despite being poorly understood. Thus, greater knowledge of its fundamental characterestics should  have significant impact on the design of future information systems with clear economic and social impact. Its study will present a very interesting attraction and challenge to graduate students and should be a great stimulus in course discussions. Attempts will also be made to interest students , not only at LSU, but also at Southern University (an HBCU).

por.por_cntn:
The smallest unit of information in classical systems (such as communication and computers) is the so-called bit, corresponding to one of two possible states labelled 0 and1. A quantum bit (a qubit) exists in a superposition of these two states so that multi-qubit entanglement enables the formation of many more states. An essential requirement for building devices is  entanglement between the qubits and the  corresponding interaction energy coupling the qubits. Thus, our goal was a first-principle investigation of qubits and their interaction and the determination of the optimum way of combining them to make devices.

Our initial goal was to solve exactly the interaction of two qubits in a common heat bath of temperature T. This goal was achieved and, in addition, serendipitous discoveries emerged. First, it became clear that new forces (called Casimir forces) came into play, an understanding of which would play a key role in assisting researchers engaged in building micro electrical-mechenical systems, which are presently hindered by surface interactions of unknown origin.

One possibility for reducing unwanted attraction is quantum friction, which became the focus of our attention. As part of our investigation, we needed to investigate how blackbody radiation behaves when one changes coordinate systems. To our surprise, a clean-cut calculation of this effect did not exist and we ended up solving a problem that many of the greats of physics had worked on for more than 100 years and that is how temperature behaves under the transformation.

We were now ready to return to the complicated problem of calculating quantum friction. This work has proceeded very well and exact results have been obtained. However, it is still not ready for publication because our analysis led to some anomalous results which led us to conclude that there are some subtle problems that need further thorough investigations.
